The post Exploiting Second Order SQL Injection with Stored Procedures appeared first on NetSPI.
articles.title: Exploiting Second Order SQL Injection with Stored Procedures

articles.author: Dmitry Janushkevich
articles.description:
The Tesla Wall Connector is a Level 2 electric vehicle charge station designed for use by residential home users. The device has a minimal user interface in its hardware, providing a Wi-Fi based interface for configuration and an NFC reader for user authentication. The device does not come with a dedicated mobile application out of the box; the initial configuration‚Äîwhich is rather minimal‚Äîis performed via the web interface. After that, the device suggests the Tesla One app is to be used for further configuration. The Tesla app allows connecting to the device but apparently can only be used to perform a few functions such as scheduled charging and viewing information about the device. It does not offer options for further configuration.
At the moment of writing, the latest software version‚Ä¶
articles.title: Detailing the Attack Surfaces of the Tesla Wall Connector EV Charger

articles.author: Piotr Bazyd≈Ço
articles.description:
Some time ago, I spent some time researching a core SolarWinds product, SolarWinds Platform (previously Orion Platform). At that time, I hadn‚Äôt been aware of the SolarWinds Access Right Manager product (Solar Winds ARM).
Afterward, Trend Micro‚Äôs Zero Day Initiative began receiving submissions of vulnerabilities in Access Rights Manager (ARM). The first submissions we received were from Sina Kheirkhah (@SinSinology), and one of those was a pre-auth RCE based on the .NET Remoting service. After his issues were patched, we received some additional, anonymous reports, in which pre-auth RCE was achieved via an unauthenticated gRPC/.NET Remoting based service on port 55555/tcp. An unauthenticated attacker was able to call its many methods, which were vulnerable mainly due to:
¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Exposing da‚Ä¶
articles.title: SolarWinds Access Rights Manager: One Vulnerability to LPE Them All

articles.author: Dustin Childs
articles.description:
We have made it to the end of the year and the final Patch Tuesday of 2024. As expected, Microsoft and Adobe have released what (hopefully) will be their last patches of the year. Take a break from your holiday preparations and join us as we review the details of their latest security alerts. If you‚Äôd rather watch the full video recap covering the entire release, you can check it out here:
Adobe Patches for December 2024
For December, Adobe released a monstrous 16 patches addressing a whopping 167 CVEs in Adobe Experience Manager, Acrobat and Reader, Media Encoder, Illustrator, After Effects, Animate, InDesign, Adobe‚ÄØPDFL Software Development Kit (SDK), Connect, Substance 3D Sampler, Photoshop, Substance 3D Modeler, Bridge, Premiere Pro, Substance 3D Painter, and FrameMaker. The largest of‚Ä¶
articles.title: The December 2024 Security Update Review

articles.author: R.Rivera
articles.description: We‚Äôre excited to announce that all of NCC Group‚Äôs latest research findings and articles are now hosted on our website at the following link: NCC Group Research Blog. (https://www.nccgroup.com/us/research-blog/) To stay up-to-date with our latest research, you can also subscribe to our RSS feed here: NCC Group Research Blog RSS Feed. (https://www.nccgroup.com/us/research-blog/feed/) Be sure to [‚Ä¶]
articles.title: New website address and RSS Feed

articles.author: Kenneth King
articles.description:
IoT security assessments expose diverse technologies, use cases, and protocols. While wireless components like WiFi and Bluetooth enhance functionality and enable features like OTA updates, they also increase the attack surface. This blog explores the challenges of assessing non-wireless IoT devices and considers the potential of adding wireless capabilities for comprehensive security testing.
The post Breaking the Air Gap Through Hardware Implants appeared first on Praetorian.
articles.title: Breaking the Air Gap Through Hardware Implants

articles.author: Kenneth King
articles.description:
Praetorian's open-source secrets detection tool, Nosey Parker, was released two years ago. Learn more about updates Nosey Parker and importance in today's environment.
The post Nosey Parker Turns Two: Celebrating Two Years of Open-Source Secrets Discovery¬† appeared first on Praetorian.
articles.title: Nosey Parker Turns Two: Celebrating Two Years of Open-Source Secrets Discovery

articles.description:
Introduction
During my recent internship with Doyensec, I had the opportunity to research decompression attacks across different programming languages. As the use of archive file formats is widespread in software development, it is crucial for developers to understand the potential security risks involved in handling these files.
The objective of my research was to identify, analyze, and detect vulnerable implementations in several popular programming languages used for web and app development, including Python, Ruby, Swift, Java, PHP, and JavaScript. These languages have libraries for archive decompression that, when used improperly, may potentially lead to vulnerabilities.
To demonstrate the risk of unsafe unpacking, I created proof-of-concept (PoC) code with different vulnerable impleme‚Ä¶
articles.title: Unsafe Archive Unpacking: Labs and Semgrep Rules

articles.author: Trail of Bits
articles.description: Ruby Central hired Trail of Bits to complete a security assessment and a competitive analysis of RubyGems.org, the official package management system for Ruby applications. With over 184+ billion downloads to date, RubyGems.org is critical infrastructure for the Ruby language ecosystem. This is a joint post with the Ruby Central team; read their announcement here! [‚Ä¶]
articles.title: Auditing the Ruby ecosystem‚Äôs central package repository

articles.author: Trail of Bits
articles.description: By Matt Schwager and Travis Peters We are publishing another set of custom Semgrep rules, bringing our total number of public rules to 115. This blog post will briefly cover the new rules, then explore two Semgrep features in depth: regex mode (especially how it compares against generic mode), and HCL language support for technologies [‚Ä¶]
articles.title: 35 more Semgrep rules: infrastructure, supply chain, and Ruby

articles.author: Andy Gill
articles.description: This post explores Windows Side-by-Side (WinSxS) and DLL hijacking, deep-diving some tooling I've written and some of the fun along the way.
articles.title: Side-by-Side with HelloJackHunter: Unveiling the Mysteries of WinSxS

articles.author: Wolfgang Miedl
articles.description:
Microsoft is introducing a new type of small language model (SLM) designed specifically for business scenarios. A recent announcement highlights several development partners and practical applications, including Bayer and Siemens Digital Industries Software. These models are intended for managing complex processes using natural language input.
Source
articles.title: Microsoft‚Äôs industry-specific small language models (SLM)

articles.author: Michael Pietroforte
articles.description:
In a recent paper, Google researchers discussed an interesting approach that reduces training time and computational cost while improving the quality of Large Language Models (LLMs). The SALT (Small Model Aided Large Model Training) method uses smaller models to guide the initial training phase of larger models through knowledge distillation (KD). SALTDS (SALT with Data Selection) extends this technique by identifying and prioritizing challenging but learnable training sequences for knowledge transfer during the KD phase.
Source
articles.title: SALT: Small Model Aided Large Model Training ‚Äì Knowledge distillation during pre-training

articles.author: Nicki Borell
articles.description:
The EU‚Äôs new AI regulation, the AI Act, mandates that AI-generated texts must be explicitly identified as such. However, given the rapid increase in AI usage, it‚Äôs doubtful whether machine-generated texts will always be transparently disclosed. To address this, AI detection tools are becoming increasingly relevant. This overview examines the reliability of AI detectors.
Source
articles.title: How reliable are AI detection tools?

articles.author: Wolfgang Miedl
articles.description:
Many businesses hold back on upgrading Office applications. Office 2016, for example, remains a common office suite even in large corporations. According to a study by Intra2Net, over 80 percent of small and medium-sized businesses are using outdated Office apps that will no longer receive official Microsoft support after 2025.
Source
articles.title: Office 2016 dominates: Small and medium-sized businesses reluctant to upgrade

articles.author: Wolfgang Sommergut
articles.description:
The Domain Name System (DNS) is susceptible to attacks that redirect clients to malicious services. Technologies like DNSSEC, DoH, and DoT have been developed to mitigate such threats. In addition, Microsoft introduced Zero Trust DNS (ZTDNS) in Windows 11, which blocks all connections unless a trusted and secure DNS server has resolved their IP addresses.
Source
articles.title: Windows 11 Zero Trust DNS (ZTDNS): Only permit outbound connections via protective DNS

articles.author: Mike Kanakos
articles.description:
Microsoft has unveiled the first release candidate of PowerShell 7.5, with the General Availability (GA) launch expected in January or February 2025. This release candidate provides the most accurate preview of the upcoming final production version of PowerShell 7.5. This new version includes hundreds of changes, ranging from minor adjustments to major new features. In the following sections, we will discuss the key changes in this major PowerShell update.
Source
articles.title: PowerShell 7.5 new features

articles.author: Michael Pietroforte
articles.description:
A recent Anthropic paper reveals that AI models demonstrate deceptive behaviors, such as lying and bypassing oversight, highlighting why current alignment strategies often fail. For me, the results of this paper come as no surprise, as it's clear that AI models lie and exhibit deceptive behavior if this maximizes the reward signal given during alignment.
Source
articles.title: When an AI lies

articles.author: Vignesh Mudliar
articles.description:
Occasionally, Microsoft 365 users cannot delete emails. Possible causes are mailbox policies or quota limitations. In this post, I will explore the typical reasons for this issue and offer step-by-step solutions.
Source
articles.title: Microsoft 365 users cannot delete emails

articles.author: Markus Elsberger
articles.description:
Azure Arc is a management platform that enables centralized control of on-premises, multi-cloud, and edge resources through the Azure Portal. In Windows Server 2025, features such as Hotpatching‚Äîwhich allows for applying security updates without requiring a system reboot‚Äîrequire integration with Azure Arc. To install Azure Arc on Windows Server 2025, use a PowerShell script or launch the Azure Arc setup wizard on your server.
Source
articles.title: Install Azure Arc on Windows Server 2025

articles.author: Wolfgang Sommergut
articles.description:
Several authentication methods are available when using Outlook as an IMAP client for Gmail. Older versions typically rely on username and password, while newer clients support more modern, secure approaches. However, users frequently face challenges accessing their mailbox if a Google account password changes.
Source
articles.title: Change Gmail password in Outlook

articles.author: Michael Pietroforte
articles.description:
Recent discussions in the AI community highlight concerns about the ‚ÄúAI Wall,‚Äù a term describing the diminishing returns observed when scaling AI models by increasing their size. This trend challenges the previously held scaling law, which posited that larger models would consistently yield better results. In this post, I summarize recent statements from prominent researchers and AI figures about their views on the AI Wall and present evidence suggesting that we have indeed hit an AI Wall.
Source
articles.title: What is the AI Wall? Prominent AI researchers about the scaling law

articles.author: Wolfgang Sommergut
articles.description:
The new Outlook falls short of meeting the functionality and quality expectations of many businesses, yet Microsoft is pressing organizations to make the switch. To block an unwanted migration to the new client, administrators can configure several Group Policy settings, including one that allows users to revert to the previous version of Outlook.
Source
articles.title: Block migration to new Outlook with Group Policy

articles.author: Surender Kumar
articles.description:
Proxmox Virtual Environment (VE), a popular open-source platform for managing virtualized infrastructure, introduces a long-awaited OVA import feature in version 8.3. This update streamlines transferring virtual machines from other hypervisors to your Proxmox setup. However, the Import Wizard introduced in Proxmox 8.2 is likely a more suitable choice for migrating VMware VMs to Proxmox. This post details how to export and import an Oracle VirtualBox VM into Proxmox using the new OVA import feature.
Source
articles.title: OVA import in Proxmox 8.3

articles.author: Wolfgang Sommergut
articles.description:
In an Active Directory domain, it is crucial to sync the system time across all computers as accurately as possible. Since the 2016 version, Windows Server can greatly minimize discrepancies in system clocks. This feature, referred to as Accurate Time, can be configured with Group Policy settings, provided that specific conditions are fulfilled.
Source
articles.title: Configure computers in an Active Directory domain for accurate time sync

articles.author: Wolfgang Sommergut
articles.description:
Windows 11 24H2 and Server 2025 improve the SMB protocol with a strong focus on security. One key feature is the ability to change ports to TCP 445, which offers enhanced security and flexibility. However, this capability is restricted to the QUIC transport on the server side.
Source
articles.title: Change SMB ports in Windows 11 and Server 2025

articles.author: Edem Afenyo
articles.description:
Microsoft has rolled out significant updates to Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL), enhancing its usability and security. This update introduces the official Red Hat Enterprise Linux (RHEL) distribution, simplifies installation with tar-based distros, and revamps the Getting Started experience with helpful documentation and tool integration. Enterprise users benefit from improved compliance and security through Intune and Microsoft Entra integration. Additionally, WSL version 2.4.4 unlocks these features, providing a smoother Linux experience within Windows.
Source
articles.title: Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL) update: Red Hat support, tar-based distros, Intune and Entra integration

articles.author: Markus Elsberger
articles.description:
Credential Guard in Windows Server 2025 enhances security by isolating credentials using Virtualization-Based Security (VBS). To enable Credential Guard with PowerShell or Group Policy, ensure your systems meet the hardware and firmware requirements. After enabling Credential Guard, you can use PowerShell to verify its activation.
Source
articles.title: Enable Credential Guard on Windows Server 2025

articles.author: Brandon Lee
articles.description:
The latest GA release of NAKIVO Backup and Replication v11 includes agentless backup support for a new hypervisor that has garnered significant interest: Proxmox. Let‚Äôs explore this and other new features in NAKIVO Backup and Replication v11.
Source
articles.title: Agentless Proxmox backups with NAKIVO Backup & Replication v11

articles.author: Markus Elsberger
articles.description:
Microsoft‚Äôs new AI Shell integrates AI into command-line workflows, featuring the Azure OpenAI Agent and Copilot in Azure Agent for tasks like PowerShell scripting and cloud automation. You can install AI Shell (aish.exe) as a standalone app or PowerShell module to streamline coding, error resolution, and resource management on Windows, macOS, or Linux.
Source
articles.title: Install and integrate Microsoft AI Shell with a PowerShell module

articles.author: adam
articles.description: In this post we explore the dism.exe and WIM images a bit more. It turns out that WIM files are containers that can include more than one image. One can create the first image using the /Capture-Image option, and then ‚Ä¶ Continue reading ‚Üí
articles.title: Smuggling payloads and tools in, using WIM images, Part 2

articles.author: adam
articles.description: The file contains 12M+ of rows, each containing a set of popular hashes, and a file name extracted from my ‚Äògood files‚Äô repo (dome dups may be found if f.ex. file name changes, but hashes don‚Äôt). These are primarily Windows-centric ‚Ä¶ Continue reading ‚Üí
articles.title: Clean hash set ‚Äì 12M rows

articles.author: adam
articles.description: We often hear of attackers bringing in their payloads via virtual drive images (f.ex. vhd,vhdx) in an attempt to bypass security solutions. The WIM files can be used to smuggle in tools and payloads to the target, too. In my ‚Ä¶ Continue reading ‚Üí
articles.title: Smuggling payloads and tools in, using WIM images

articles.author: adam
articles.description: In my old post I listed a number of ‚Äògood Alternate Data Streams (ADS)‚Äô, and one of them was called $WIMMOUNTDATA. I just came across the very same ADS again during one of my procmon tests, so I decided to ‚Ä¶ Continue reading ‚Üí
articles.title: WIMMOUNTDATA ADS

articles.author: adam
articles.description: When you run MoNotificationUxStub.exe on Windows Server 2025, it will try to load the following non-existing library: C:\Windows\UUS\amd64\UMPDC.dll We can place our own, leading to the code execution: Same as in the previous case, TrustedInstaller rights are required to write ‚Ä¶ Continue reading ‚Üí
articles.title: MoNotificationUxStub.exe lolbin

articles.author: adam
articles.description: When you run MLEngineStub.exe on Windows 2025, it will try to locate the following non-existing executable: C:\Windows\UUS\amd64\MLEngine.exe So, if we place our own executable there, it will be launched: The only caveat ‚Äì only TrustedInstaller can write to this folder.
articles.title: MLEngineStub.exe lolbin

articles.author: adam
articles.description: When you run la57setup.exe or OOBEFodSetup.exe on Windows Server 2025, they will try to load a non-existing library from the path below: C:\Windows\System32\Dism\MetaDeployProvider.dll
articles.title: la57setup.exe & OOBEFodSetup.exe lolbin

articles.author: adam
articles.description: It is typical for many of us to discover ‚Äòthe cool thing‚Äô, and then quickly move on to research something else. Over the last few years my ‚Äòlittle known secrets‚Äô series exploited this phenomenon by showcasing scenarios that, admittedly, were ‚Ä¶ Continue reading ‚Üí
articles.title: 3 little secrets of netsh.exe

articles.author: adam
articles.description: In my previous post I have provided a long list of paths Windows Defender is trying to access when the Windows Server 2022 starts. Since the Windows Server 2025 is now available, I thought it would be interesting to repeat ‚Ä¶ Continue reading ‚Üí
articles.title: Windows Server 2025 and MsMpEng.exe

articles.author: adam
articles.description: I did consider writing about: C:\Windows\System32\WptsExtensions.dll but this phantom DLL has been documented all over the place, so let‚Äôs look at a different one: C:\Windows\System32\XboxNetApiSvcExtHost.dll It‚Äôs loaded by svchost.exe on Windows 11 24H2 and Windows Server 2022.
articles.title: Beyond good ol‚Äô Run key, Part 146

articles.author: adam
articles.description: Windows Server 2022 launches ctfmon.exe during its start and this process‚Äô DLL dependencies lead to an execution path that loads a phantom (non-existing) library: C:\Windows\System32\LangDownloader.dll So, you can drop your own and enjoy your stay!
articles.title: Beyond good ol‚Äô Run key, Part 145

articles.author: adam
articles.description: Running Procmon in a boot mode is a very powerful research tool. In this short post I want to share a Procmon boot log of MsMpEng.exe (Windows Defender process) where we clearly see it is attempting to access a lot ‚Ä¶ Continue reading ‚Üí
articles.title: Windows Server 2022 and MsMpEng.exe

articles.author: adam
articles.description: This is not a proper research yet. I just happened to stumble upon an interesting artifact which is a file: C:\Windows\System32\dns\RFC5011.csv that dns.exe service process tries to read. This csv file appears to be related to DNSSEC, but I don‚Äôt ‚Ä¶ Continue reading ‚Üí
articles.title: dns.exe and its quirks

articles.author: adam
articles.description: I asked myself what tangible artifacts present on a file system can immediately tell us that the server system in place is a Domain Controller and/or DNS server. I decided to run a simple experiment. I installed a test version ‚Ä¶ Continue reading ‚Üí
articles.title: Promoting a Windows 2022 server to Domain Controller and DNS Server

articles.author: adam
articles.description: This old series is not very exciting. Decompiling goodware installation scripts will never lead us to newsworthy discoveries ‚Äì feel free to stop reading now. Many installers copy files, add/change registry keys and values, install services, drivers, and do all ‚Ä¶ Continue reading ‚Üí
articles.title: Not installing the installers, part 4

articles.author: adam
articles.description: If you have ASRock Polychrome RGB installed on your system you may find this interesting executable in one of its subfolders: c:\Program Files (x86)\ASRock Utility\ASRRGBLED\HAL\ExecCmd64.exe It is signed: Verified: SignedSigning date: 2:11 AM 3/16/2023Publisher: ASROCK INC.Company: n/aDescription: n/aProduct: n/aProd version: ‚Ä¶ Continue reading ‚Üí
articles.title: ExecCmd64 lolbin

articles.author: PTP Aviation Team
articles.description:
Introduction Safety and transparency are important in aviation. One tool that helps here is the Cockpit Voice Recorder (CVR), which records audio from the cockpit during flights. It is crucial [‚Ä¶]
The surprising existence of the erase button on cockpit voice recorders first appeared on Pen Test Partners.
articles.title: The surprising existence of the erase button on cockpit voice recorders

articles.author: Ken Munro
articles.description:
TL;DR A silly-season BLE connectivity story Overheat people‚Äôs smart ski socks ‚Ä¶but only when in Bluetooth range AND when the owner‚Äôs phone is out of range of their feet! Having [‚Ä¶]
Heels on fire. Hacking smart ski socks first appeared on Pen Test Partners.
articles.title: Heels on fire. Hacking smart ski socks

articles.description:
I regularly look at how the system prompts of chatbots change over time. Updates frequently highlight new features being added, design changes that occur and potential areas that might benefit from more security scrutiny.
A few months back I noticed an interesting update to the M365 Copilot (BizChat) system prompt. In particular, there used to be one enterprise_search tool in the past. You might remember that tool was used during the Copirate ASCII Smuggling exploit to search for MFA codes in the user‚Äôs inbox.
articles.title: Microsoft 365 Copilot Generated Images Accessible Without Authentication -- Fixed!

articles.description:
Happy to share that I authored the paper ‚ÄúTrust No AI: Prompt Injection Along The CIA Security Triad‚Äù, based on research conducted over the past 18 months.
You can download it from arxiv.
The paper examines how prompt injection attacks compromise Confidentiality, Integrity, and Availability (CIA) of AI systems, with real-world examples targeting vendors like OpenAI, Google, Anthropic and Microsoft.
It summarizes and references many of the prompt injection examples I explained on this blog, and I hope this research helps bridge the gap between traditional cybersecurity practices and AI research, fostering stronger defenses against these emerging threats.
articles.title: Trust No AI: Prompt Injection Along the CIA Security Triad Paper

articles.description:
Grok is the chatbot of xAI. It‚Äôs a state-of-the-art model, chatbot and recently also API. It has a Web UI and is integrated into the X (former Twitter) app, and recently it‚Äôs also accessible via an API.
Since this post is a bit longer, I‚Äôm adding an index for convenience:
Table of Contents  High Level Overview Analyzing Grok‚Äôs System Prompt Prompt Injection from Other User‚Äôs Posts Prompt Injection from Images Prompt Injection from PDFs Conditional Prompt Injection and Targeted Disinformation Data Exfiltration - End-to-End Demonstration Rendering of Clickable Hyperlinks to Phishing Sites ASCII Smuggling - Crafting Invisible Text and Decoding Hidden Secrets  Hidden Prompt Injection Creation of Invisible Text Grok API is also Vulnerable to ASCII Smuggling Developer Guidance for Grok API   Automatic Tool Invocation Responsible Disclosure Conclusion  High Level Overview Over the last year I have used Grok quite a bit.
articles.title: Security ProbLLMs in xAI's Grok: A Deep Dive

articles.description:
Last week Leon Derczynski described how LLMs can output ANSI escape codes. These codes, also known as control characters, are interpreted by terminal emulators and modify behavior.
This discovery resonates with areas I had been exploring, so I took some time to apply, and build upon, these newly uncovered insights.
ANSI Terminal Emulator Escape Codes Here is a simple example that shows how to render blinking, colorful text using control characters.
articles.title: Terminal DiLLMa: LLM-powered Apps Can Hijack Your Terminal Via Prompt Injection

articles.author: Damien Gremes
articles.description:
You just had your first encounter with the "Headless Chicken Effect" during a security incident, like we mentioned in our last blog post. Maybe you like to be prepared against any possible scenario because you know that it's not a matter of 'if', but rather a matter of 'when'? 
In this second blogpost in our "Ransomware Readiness" series, we'll look into how you can better prepare yourself to face such incidents in the future, whether it's through planning, documentation, or testing.
articles.title: Your Playbook to a better Incident Response Plan

The term ‚Äúspecial relationship,‚Äù coined by Winston Churchill, describes the close, longstanding alliance between the United States and the United Kingdom. It has been applied to cooperation during war, to trade and commerce, and even to intelligence sharing. That special relationship has clearly influenced the two nations‚Äô recent policy papers on national cybersecurity. The U.K. [‚Ä¶]

In 2022, 18,828 common vulnerabilities and exposures (CVEs) were published. At the same time, organization attack surfaces are expanding. [‚Ä¶]

Now that the ink is dry on the 35-page document, top officials like Acting National Cyber Director Kemba Walden are busy putting it into [‚Ä¶]
The post The U.S. has a new cybersecurity strategy. What‚Äôs next for CISOs? appeared first on Synack.
articles.title: The U.S. has a new cybersecurity strategy. What‚Äôs next for CISOs?

articles.author: Marc Smeets
articles.description:
As 2024 nears its end, we feel it is a great time to look back at what we achieved in 2024.
TLDR: No one would call this a quiet year for Outflank.
OST Releases: New Tools and Major Releases
22 releases! We managed to put out 22 releases of OST in 2024.
Rapid development remains a cornerstone of OST and has allowed us to match the pace of evolving threat landscape to deliver cutting edge tools and capabilities. We have a release note tracker covering every release, but highlights include:
EDR Presets
With EDRs becoming more powerful, and bypasses requiring more EDR-specific tricks, it was becoming hard to keep track of the countless options OST operators have for evasion of those EDRs.

Read full post
The post 2024 Wrapped: Outflank‚Äôs Top Tracks appeared first on Outflank.
articles.title: 2024 Wrapped: Outflank‚Äôs Top Tracks
